label: CRWB Incident Position Description
Prior to mobilization, confirm crew meets English language/crew language requirements.
Travel to and check in at assignment.
Ensure individual readiness.
Gather critical information pertinent to the assignment.
Review Incident Action Plan (IAP) and obtain briefing, objectives, and intent from supervisor.
Brief assigned personnel using IAP and/or Incident Response Pocket Guide (IRPG), PMS 461, briefing checklist.
Establish and communicate chain of command, reporting procedures, risk management processes, and radio frequency management.
Participate in operational briefings as directed.
Ensure that IAP or relevant plan lists correct crew status. Report any corrections up chain of command.
Establish a common operating picture with supervisors and subordinates.
Assemble and validate readiness of crew, equipment, and vehicles.
Base actions on evolving situational awareness and communicate changes to appropriate personnel.
Model leadership values and principles. Provide positive influence. Emphasize teamwork.
Monitor personnel daily performance and provide feedback.
Identify, analyze, and use relevant situational information to make informed decisions and take appropriate actions.
Establish and communicate performance expectations.
Ensure incident objectives and leader’s intent (task, purpose, end state) are met.
Supervise felling operations, including appropriate snag mitigation.
Supervise water handling logistics and operations for crew (e.g., portable pumps, hoses, fold-a-tanks).
Prepare control lines for burnout operations.
Supervise mop-up and suppression repair efforts on assigned portion of line.
Coordinate and communicate issues with fireline supervisor and adjoining resources.
Plan, direct, and supervise firing operations.
Effectively lead crew operations.
Determine appropriate fireline tactics, including indirect and direct attack strategies.
Properly locate fireline and determine appropriate fireline construction methods necessary to stop fire spread. Ensure completion to acceptable standards.
Ensure proper refurbishing and resupply of tools, vehicles, food, water, and supplies.
Scout line in critical areas and patrol fireline for spot fires and slop overs.
Verify driver/operator qualifications and ensure adherence to vehicle safety procedures when transporting personnel, fuel, and equipment.

Through established chain of command, assist the responsible land management agency and/or assigned Resource Advisor (READ), with the protection of natural, cultural, and other resources. Communicate when such resources are discovered and document suppression impacts.
Equip crew with appropriate short and long-term logistical needs for assignment and utilize correct procedures to obtain additional supplies.
Develop and implement tactics based on incident objectives, fire behavior, risk assessment and leader's intent.
Provide timely updates of accurate information and recommendations using the chain of command to assist with the planning process.
Assess work area to meet assigned objectives.
Report special occurrences (e.g., structure/improved property loss or damage, accidents, sickness) to supervisor.
Assign personnel to collect, document, and report weather observations.
Gather and/or disseminate information using maps, compass, Global Positioning System (GPS), and other tools and applications.

Coordinate travel to and from fireline (e.g., travel routes, communication procedures, accountability). Ensure adherence to vehicle safety procedures. Identify ingress and egress routes. Consider bridge and road limits, equipment weight and length, and weather effects.
Request, direct, and provide feedback to aerial resources through established chain of command.
Provide status updates on conditions affecting operations, hazardous conditions, unresolved conflicts, air operations, etc., to supervisor.
Organize and deploy crew based on current objectives and resource capabilities.
Provide situation update and accomplishments to supervisor and/or relief forces at end of shift.
Conduct WUI operations according to guidelines stated in IRPG, incident-specific objectives and guidelines, and agency-specific guidance.
Establish communications and exchange necessary briefings/information.
Conduct and/or participate in After Action Reviews (AAR).
Use plain language and ICS terminology.
Follow established processes and chain of command for collecting, producing, and distributing information.
Ensure clear understanding of expectations and timely communication within and across Incident Command System (ICS) functional areas and chain of command.
Prepare and program radios for assignment.
Communicate effectively using multichannel radios.

Plan for medical emergencies. Ensure that assigned resources are prepared to execute the Medical Plan (ICS 206 WF). Ensure familiarity with medical responders, communication procedures, and transportation plan.
Submit accident/incident reports with pertinent forms (SAFECOM, SAFENET, agency-specific forms) through established chain of command.
Develop and communicate contingency plans and trigger points.
Use Look Up, Down and Around in IRPG to help maintain situational awareness. Adjust actions accordingly.
Provide input into the risk management process to ensure safety of operations.
Manage a medical emergency based on procedures stated in the IAP, the IRPG, Medical Incident Report, or other relevant guidelines.

Apply the Risk Management Process as stated in the IRPG:
Identify Hazards.
Assess Hazards.
Develop Controls and Make Risk Decisions.
Implement Controls.
Supervise and Evaluate.
Ensure Lookouts, Communications, Escape Routes, and Safety Zones (LCES) is in place.
Monitor for signs and symptoms of fatigue, illness, or injury. Mitigate appropriately.
Account for location, health, safety, and welfare of assigned personnel.
Complete all administrative tasks and documentation in an accurate and timely manner.
Depart from incident.
Prepare for and Implement Demobilization.
Apply principles of Operational Risk Management.
Acquire, analyze, and use relevant situational information to make more informed decisions and take appropriate actions.
Ensure Lookouts, Communications, Escape Routes, and Safety Zones (LCES) are established and known to all firefighters before they are needed. Refer to guidelines stated in IRPG.
Use Look Up, Down and Around in IRPG to help maintain situational awareness. Adjust actions accordingly. Develop and communicate contingency plans and trigger points.

Plan for medical emergencies. Ensure that assigned resources are prepared to execute the Medical Plan (ICS 206 WF). Ensure familiarity with medical responders, communication procedures, and transportation plan. Manage the medical emergency based on procedures stated in the IAP, the IRPG Medical Incident Report, or other relevant guidelines.

Complete, authorize, ensure timeliness of, and route as required. Common Administrative Forms:  Incident Personnel Performance Rating (ICS 225 WF). General Message (ICS 213). Activity Log (ICS 214). Agency-specific forms.  Position Specific: Crew Time Report (CTR), SF-261 (Watch: How to correctly fill out a CTR) OWCP Forms: CA1, CA2, CA16
Develop and communicate contingency plans and trigger points.
According to agency policy and type of crew, perform the duties and responsibilities of CRWB as needed.
Communicate and coordinate Aircrew and Base Personnel needs.
Communicate changing conditions to supervisor.

Collect and record accurate daily flight and cost data, landing fees, and retardant use. Submit required forms to the appropriate personnel by close of business (COB) daily. Maintain all use records per agency guidelines.

Plan for medical emergencies. Ensure that assigned resources are prepared to execute the Medical Plan (ICS 206 WF). Ensure familiarity with medical responders, communication procedures, and transportation plan. Manage the medical emergency based on procedures stated in the IAP, the IRPG Medical Incident Report, or other relevant guidelines.
Coordinate with other sections during demobilization to ensure the return of accountable property to the appropriate owner, e.g., incident agency, or local, geographic, or national cache.
Update supervisor on current accomplishments and/or concerns.
Recon the ignition unit or assigned area.
Apply Aviation Safety & Risk Management Systems to include Policy, Risk Management, Assurance, and Promotion.
Demonstrate ability to successfully use communication equipment.

Determine appropriate aircraft for mission based on flight request information, mission requirement, locations, special circumstances, availability, and cost effectiveness.  Complete a cost comparison if necessary.
Establish positive communication with swampers, crew, and supervisor.
Provide estimated costs to date and anticipated total costs.
Maintain a log of strategic decisions and significant events for inclusion in the Area Command final documentation package.
Demonstrate knowledge of expanded dispatch positions and structure.
Identify resources available for reassignment.
Assist supervisor in preparing operational briefing materials.
Ensures all airtanker base personnel are trained in identifying properly secured GSE.
Operate within current certification and qualification level, except during formal evaluation proceedings or under the immediate supervision of a higher qualified sawyer.
Ensure that Finance/Administration section has necessary inspection documentation for assigned resources.
Review the status of all orders in the assigned functional area.
Designate safe zones for Ground Support Equipment (GSE).
Operate within your skill level and turn down any saw operation you feel is unsafe or when the complexity is higher than your certification or ability.
Distribute contract documents according to established guidelines.
Conduct an aerial survey of incident operations airspace.
Complete test fire according to plan.
Serve as the primary logistics representative when working at a remote spike camp.
Receive and follow demobilization instructions from supervisor.
Adjust actions based on changing information and evolving situation awareness. Communicate changing conditions to your incident supervisor.
Coordinate with Resource Advisor (READ) regarding potential helispots, helibases, mobile retardant base, helicopter dip sites, and fixed-wing aircraft scooping locations.
Coordinate travel (e.g., travel routes, communication procedures, and accountability). Ensure adherence to vehicle safety procedures. Identify ingress and egress routes.
Document all complaints and suspicious occurrences.
Adhere to the chain of command as it applies to crew configuration.
Communicate and coordinate with the Communications Unit Leader (COML) concerning frequency needs and assignments.
Perform all functions of various Finance Unit Leaders that are not activated.
Maintain a supply of water and chemical agent for the fire, particularly on critical areas of the fireline.
In absence of IARR, contact home agency within 12 hours after arriving at incident and inform of situation, status, and location.
Monitor restrictions/work requirements for each resource to maximize safe and efficient assignments and demobilization.
Identify ingress and egress routes.
Ensure thorough investigation and documentation of actual and potential claims for and against the government are in place to maintain cost management measures.
Coordinate with Federal Aviation Agency (FAA).
Distribute information (flight/load limits, etc.) to base personnel.
Verify that hand crew leadership [Crew Boss (CRWB), Firefighter Type 1 (FFT1)] meet English language/crew language comprehension requirement.
Adhere to safety procedures for foot travel and transporting saw, fuel, personnel, and equipment.
Collect and record accurate daily flight and cost data, landing fees, and retardant use.

Plan for medical emergencies. Ensure that assigned resources are prepared to execute the Medical Plan (ICS 206 WF). Ensure familiarity with medical responders, communication procedures, and transportation plan. Manage the medical emergency based on procedures stated in the IAP, the Medical Incident Report, or other relevant guidelines.

Ensure effective exchange of information between agency management and expanded dispatch organization.
Expectations of management.
Delegated authorities.
Advise management, identify alternatives, and make recommendations.
Implement management direction.
Facilitate initial and continued contact with the incident Agency Administrator regarding agency requirements and expectations, Incident Finance Package, and closeout requirements.
Ensure hazard trees are identified, communicated, and avoided until they are mitigated.
Develop and implement contingency plans. Communicate changing conditions to assigned resources and supervisor.
Ensure that the SABO, NWCG Standards for Single Engine Airtanker Operations, PMS 506, OSHA, Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Reports, and/or agency forms and reports are completed as required.
Monitor prioritize, and coordinate radio traffice involving multiple frequencies.
Conduct warning shout (Falling!) before a backcut is started, and again as a tree begins to commit to the lay.
Follow established procedures for financial coordination with the jurisdictional agency and for the maintenance of finance, property procurement, personnel records, and forms.
Establish accurate logistical needs for assigned resources using established ordering procedures.
Provide on the spot correction of safety concerns and issues.
Support aviation flight operations:

Apply the Risk Management Process as stated in the Incident Response Pocket Guide (IRPG), PMS 461:
Identify Hazards
Assess Hazards
Develop Controls and Make Risk Decisions
Implement Controls
Request and post updated aerial hazard and temporary flight restriction (TFR) maps from area forest, district, unit, or land managers.
Develop and/or implement local Airtanker Base Operations Plan (ABOP) providing for and enforcing accountability, safety, and security measures for personnel and resources.
Utilize reference guides to validate resource capabilities, limitation, or regulations governing use.
Follow safe working conditions and guidelines provided by your supervisor.
Obtain the Modular Airborne Firefighting System (MAFFS) Operating Plan if the base is MAFFS approved.
Cut material to a size that is moveable by hand.
Coordinate an efficient transfer of your position duties when demobilizing.
Coordinate a consistent communication strategy among the IMTs based on AA direction.
Utilize established methods and ordering channels.
Assess experience level of assigned personnel prior to fireline assignment.
Fully functional and maintained chainsaw
Complete the Emergency Equipment Use Envelope, OF 305.
Recognize incident and resource allocation priorities and direct the processing of resource orders appropriately.
Be prepared to work a functional area desk if there are position shortages.
Use firing devices under supervision on a firing operation according to the ignition/firing plan (verbal or written).
Ensure the provisions in the cooperative agreements include direction for incident business management and related record keeping.
Ensure contractors and cooperators are managed properly in accordance with the terms and conditions of the agreement/contract.

Evaluate the airspace surrounding the incident to identify airspace conflicts or impacts to air operations, such as military operating areas (MOA), military training routes (MTR), special-use airspace (SUA), visual flight rules (VFR) airways, or airports.
Ensure the completion of cost analysis data on alternative control operations as required.
Request additional communications services (e.g., telephone, satcom, microwave) when necessary.
Evaluate and share all functional information for logistics with Area Command team members.
Report all accidents or injuries to supervisor.
Ensure that all claims are processed in accordance with incident agency procedures and policies.
Determine coordination procedures for use by air organization with ground branches, divisions, groups, and other incident sections.
Perform daily preventative maintenance checks.
Ensure 2 ½ tree lengths distance from other personnel when felling and that all work areas are clear.
Review delegation of authority for initial attack responsibility, aerial ignition operations, communication procedures, and other items that will impact incident air operations.
Use Incident Command System (ICS) terminology, organization, and command structure.
Ensure all tort claims are filed in the Incident Claims Case File Envelope, OF-314, and in the Incident Finance Package.
Assemble and validate readiness of assigned personnel and equipment.
Upon demobilization, report status to home unit including reassignment or ETA to home unit.
Recon area of responsibility and assess feasibility of assigned objectives.
Identify political, social, economic, and sensitive issues early and deal with them in a professional and timely manner.
Complete required agency reports and Aircraft Contract Daily Diary information after each operational period for aircraft and submits to the Contracting Officers Representative (COR).

Ensure hazard trees are identified, communicated, and avoided until they are mitigated. This includes snags, hung up, and lodged trees.
If the hazard tree is not felled or removed, it shall be flagged, and no work shall be conducted within two tree lengths.
Through established chain of command, assist the responsible land management agency and/or assigned Resource Advisor (READ), with the protection of natural, cultural, and other resources.
Develop, update, or review, a mishap response plan; ensure plan is posted.
Ensure compliance with established dispatch protocols.
Return equipment and supplies to appropriate unit.
Communicate effectively using multichannel radios. Use plain language and Incident Command System (ICS) terminology.
Enforce all safety requirements for work area.
Answer the telephone and radio; receive and relay orders for aircraft dispatches.
Coordinate with local unit, OSC, and assigned aviation assets regarding aviation initial attack responses within and outside of the incident Temporary Flight Restriction. (TFR).
Identify and assess risks or hazards
Review the Organizational Needs Analysis (ONA) for current and expected conditions of all incidents under the team’s command.
Obtain information necessary to request or process a non-commercial logistical flight for personnel or cargo and flight follow to ensure flight has arrived safely.
Obtain Firing Boss (FIRB) as complexity warrants.
Conduct an After Action Review (AAR) with team members prior to release.
Identify and evaluate stressful situations or problem areas and make adjustments to correct the situation.
Utilize other alternatives to power saw felling when needed due to hazard tree complexity (e.g., heavy equipment, fireline explosives, burnout).
Coordinate with FACL to establish incident facilities.
Ensure reference guides/materials are available for each functional area.
Ensure assigned resources have all necessary equipment and supplies to meet tactical objectives. Establish long-term, multiple-shift logistical needs. Plan ahead and think strategically.
Use Look Up, Down and Around in the IRPG to help maintain situational awareness. Adjust actions accordingly.
Adjust work assignments as needed to meet operational support.
Prepare Incident Radio Communications Plan (ICS 205):
Set up expanded operations:
Participate in briefing with Agency Administrator(s).
Ensure basic understanding of multichannel radio operation. Use plain language and ICS terminology.
Provide financial summary information on current incident operations to the hosting agency representative, as well as to Command and General Staff (C&G).
Ensure plan is independent of local frequencies to prevent conflict.

Coordinate information sharing with personnel external to the IMT: local airport authority, media, landowners, local unit dispatch, unit aviation manager, adjacent incident personnel, and/or Area Command.
Follow crew standard operating procedures (SOPs).
Coordinate planned release of aviation assets with the local dispatch, geographic area aircraft coordinators, and/or national aircraft coordinators.
Be a student of fire.
Establish communications and exchange necessary briefings/information with the following:
Maintain and summarize tactical aircraft use and cost information and relay this information daily to the incident air operations staff upon supervisor approval.
Identify and safely mitigate hazards inherent with wildland urban interface (WUI) during chain saw operations.
Review or identify the final package requirements for each incident based on local agency requirements and IMT specifications.
Complete demobilization checkout process before being released from the incident.
Support aviation flight operations.
Identify elements of complexity that are not readily perceived but gained through personal experiences.
Identify, analyze, and use relevant situational information to make more informed decisions and take appropriate actions.
Coordinate an efficient transfer of position duties and complete the transition document or the closeout report for the Cost Unit at the end of the assignment.
Manage the medical emergency based on procedures stated in the Incident Action Plan (IAP), Medical Incident Report, or other relevant guidelines.
Conduct briefings with relief dispatchers.
Safely and efficiently mitigate identified conditions.
Use standard terminology, symbols, designators, and acronyms.
Submit agency Incident/Accident Reports and SAFECOMs per agency policy.
If additional staffing is required, work with the dispatch center and local Geographic Area Coordination Center (GACC) to place resource orders.

Locate emergency guides and plans such as search and rescue, continuity of operations, hazardous materials, and others. Identify responsibilities for activation of these varied emergency plans and ensure that assigned resources are prepared to execute the emergency plans.
Resolve all safety concerns encountered in any aspect of aircraft, ramp, and/or personnel operations.
Establish meetings and/or conference call schedule as needed with IMTs, geographic areas, and/or Multi-Agency Coordination (MAC) groups.
Assess experience level of assigned personnel prior to fireline assignment. Discuss performance capabilities and limitations prior to assignment.
Ensure work assignments are completed and special instructions are followed. Monitor work progress and evaluate incident situation.
Identify political or agency issues that may impact the IMTs or the incidents under their command.
Report special occurrences (e.g., structure/improved property loss or damage, accidents, sickness, road closures) to supervisor.
Review contacts, memoranda of understanding, and cooperative agreements for incident impact and application.
Coordinate the role of expanded dispatch within the incident management operation for each incident.
Identify and anticipate operational needs and request additional resources and/or replacements as needed.
Provide information to the IMT, the incident agency, and the agency responsible for payment, as requested, e.g., management information reports or accrual reports.
Review Incident Action Plans (IAPs) for consistency with strategy and common operating picture.
Conduct monitoring and observation operations according to the 10 Standard Fire Orders, 18 Watch Out Situations, and Lookouts, Communications, Escape Routes, Safety Zones (LCES).
Coordinate with Medical Unit for medical evacuation plan.
Establish housing and transportation availability for incoming dispatchers or resources that are not self-sufficient.
Complete final incident package for return to unit.
Assess the experience level of assigned personnel and discuss performance capabilities and any limitations.
Order additional resources when necessary.
Coordinate information sharing with Incident Management Team (IMT) functional areas.
Apply knowledge of fuels, terrain, weather, and fire behavior to decisions and actions.
Submit completed original documents at the appropriate time (e.g., each operational period, final package).

Plan for medical emergencies. Ensure that assigned resources are prepared to execute the Medical Plan (ICS 206 WF). Manage the medical emergency based on procedures stated in the IAP, Medical Incident Report, or other relevant guidelines.
Confirm that relevant plan has all assigned resources listed.
Oversee other dispatchers in planning flight schedules, dispatching aircraft, flight following aircraft, and frequency management, if applicable.
Multiple complex binds that are present during bucking operations (i.e., blowdown, jackstrewn, or storm damage events).
These changes must be forwarded immediately to the dispatch center that will initiate a new order to the FAA.
In absence of an EDSP perform EDSP duties.
Ensure the correct payment center is identified on the Emergency Equipment Use Invoice, OF- 286.
Adjust actions based on changing information and evolving situation awareness. Develop and implement contingency plans. Communicate changing conditions to assigned resources and supervisor.
Inform other dispatch centers and the Geographic Area Coordination Center (GACC) of tactical aircraft availability.
Develop safe working condition guidelines to manage highly complex cutting operations when options are limited: turn down any unsafe assignment.
Manage the medical emergency based on procedures stated in the Incident Action Plan (IAP), the Medical Incident Report, or other relevant guidelines.
Scout line in critical areas and patrol fireline for spot fires and slop overs.  Coordinate and communicate issues with adjoining forces.
Provide information to the Incident Management Team (IMT), the incident agency, and the agency responsible for payment, as requested.

Review emergency equipment shift tickets for adherence to contract/agreement terms and conditions and to the NWCG Standards for Interagency Incident Business Management, PMS 902, regarding; pay regulations, on-shift/off-shift time, down time, posting of commissary/deductions, approvals/signatures, and any special considerations in the Remarks block.
Review local area aviation plans and obtain initial briefing from supervisor.
Ensure familiarity with medical responders, communication procedures, and transportation plan.
Relay incident information and reload bases to responding aircraft.

Review Emergency Equipment Shift Tickets, OF-297, for adherence to contract/agreement terms and conditions and to the NWCG Standards for Interagency Incident Business Management, PMS 902, regarding: pay regulations, on-shift/off-shift time, down time, posting of commissary/deductions, approvals/signatures, and any special considerations in the Remarks Block.
Monitor ground operations for safety during loading, taxi, and fueling operations.
Provide related information on daily aircraft status or changes; maintain contact with Contracting Officer’s Representative (COR) or Project Inspector (PI) for the aircraft.
Establish communications and exchange necessary briefings/information.
Monitor personnel for signs and symptoms of fatigue, illness, or injury. Mitigate appropriately.
Ensure that all original documents are provided to documentation unit and delivered to respective agencies at the termination of Area Command.
Ensure proper use, servicing, and maintenance of felling equipment.
Communicate aircraft and staffing status to dispatch on a daily basis.
Monitor and address air quality impacts to personnel and the public. Consider potential for smoke impacts to roads, communities, and incident facilities.
Establish accurate logistical needs for assigned resources and use established ordering procedures.
Develop broad objectives for the impacted area and coordinate the development of individual incident objectives and strategies.
Document first order fire effects related to fire treatment or management objectives and constraints.
Ensure the Incident Finance Package follows the guidelines outlined in the NWCG Standards for Interagency Incident Business Management, PMS 902.
Facilitate the processing of intelligence information:
Coordinate and prioritize activities with aviation operations.
Meet with AA and receive a Delegation of Authority and other pertinent documentation as applicable to the incident.
Collect appropriate fuel, soil, and vegetation samples for moisture analysis.
Review IAP for correct frequencies.
Monitor length of commitment and seek opportunities for reassignment of incident resources.
Ensure individual readiness
Carry IRPG at all times and use it to guide actions.

Anticipate demobilization, identify excess resources, and coordinate with incident supervisor to prepare the demobilization schedule. Brief subordinate staff on the demobilization procedures and responsibilities.
Crew Time Report (CTR), SF-261 (Watch:  How to correctly fill out a CTR) and/or Emergency Firefighter Time Report, OF-288
Look, listen, and learn.
Ensure retardant lot acceptance and quality assurance procedures are followed by routing samples accordingly.
Coordinate with incident personnel who have pertinent information to be included in a claim (e.g., ground support, law enforcement, security personnel).
Determine all initial attack equipment that has not completed inspection.
Ensure that dispatchers relay new or changed frequencies and air/ground contacts when ordering additional aircraft for an incident.​
Return equipment and supplies as appropriate.
Ensure fireline personnel, aerial supervision, and pilots report known misapplications of wildland fire chemicals near avoidance areas according to local protocol.

Coordinate with supervisors and all assigned firing and holding resources to ensure ignition patterns and sequence are known and understood, and that associated actions to provide for personnel safety are carried out.
Ensure financial documentation packages are submitted to the processing agency.
Resource Order form
Ensure incident objectives and performance standards are met.
Coordinate incident infrared flight requests.
Report special incidents/accidents utilizing the SAFECOM system or other appropriate means.

Planning and preparation:
Review relevant plan.
Develop or review the firing plant and provide information and recommendations through established chain of command.
Use maps, compass, Global Positioning System (GPS) and other tools and applications to gather information and navigate on incident.
Recon area of reponsibility and assess feasibility of assigned objectives.
Calculate/estimate ability to achieve:  Overall objectives of project or treatment, Desired fire effects
Consult with supervisor on resource needs.
Assign personnel to collect, document, and report weather observations.
Identify and utilize appropriate combinations of resources to conduct firing operations:  Obtain firing platforms and devices specific to terrain, fuel type, access, and other factors (e.g., Terra Torch, helitorch, drip torch) as identified in relevant plan. NOTE:  The prescribed fire burn plan or other operational plan provided to the FIRB may specifically limit what firing devices may be considered.
Ensure assigned firing resources are equipped and capable of carrying out the ignition plan:  Provide resources with overview of the operation so they can properly equip and prepare for it.  Ensure logistical needs are met such as how and where to obtain and transport fuel to the work site or staging areas, etc.
Coordinate ignition operations with holding forces.
Ensure all paperwork and documentation is complete before disassembly of crews.
Gather critical information relevant to the assignment.
Ensure adequate airtanker base staffing.
Perform duties in accordance with local, geographic area, and national policies, standards, procedures, and guides.
Adhere to Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) requirements.
Serve as liaison or advisor between crew(s), home agency, and fireline supervisor.
Coordinate with Agency Administrator or designee and LSC to identify location for incident facilities.
Obtain briefing from previous shift/assignment position as necessary.
Check out with appropriate agency or incident personnel prior to departure and complete closeout/debriefing.
Ensure clear understanding of expectations and timely communication within and across ICS functional areas and chain of command.
Establish air support protocols and communications. Coordinate and prioritize activities with aviation operations.
Plan and activate the Finance Section by identifying units within the section to be activated and ordering resources required for section operation. Define workspace requirements and locations.
Ensure IMTs are reviewing WFDSS documentation for compliance with AA direction and compatibility among incidents, safety, and cost effectiveness.
Monitor and record fire behavior data throughout the fire management operation.
Identify and correct training deficiencies.
Calculate amount and type of additional resources required; obtain through established ordering procedures.

Assist in developing Area Command demobilization priorities and procedures.
Obtain appropriate work materials, supplies, and equipment to complete assignment.
Acquire resource ordering access for local center and establish roles.
Review and understand agreement/contract language and scope of work.
Ensure aircraft and pilots are carded and meet all agency, Department of the Interior, and Office of Aviation Service (OAS) requirements for the appropriate mission.
Comply with all safety practices and agency established standard chainsaw operating procedures.
Designate safe zones for Ground Support Equipment (GSE). Ensures all airtanker base personnel are trained in identifying properly secured GSE.
Determine work/space requirements, location, and procurement procedures for the Area Command team.
Release and/or reassign resources.
Coordinate with appropriate unit leaders to schedule inspections.
Ensure that federally-contracted aircraft are only loaded with fire chemicals on the Qualified Products List (QPL) list, https://www.fs.fed.us/rm/fire/wfcs/index.htm.
Cut and remove fuels to reduce fuel continuity to lower the threat of fire spread and reduce exposure to improved properties.
Determine supplies needed to maintain equipment.
Request that the airport manager/FAA/vendor requests a Notice to Airmen (NOTAM) that informs the public when an FAA Temporary Tower has been established.
Obtain briefing from previous ATBM, Fixed Wing Base Manager (FWBM), or Single Engine Airtanker Manager (SEMG) as necessary.
Stay informed on the number of aircraft available and the types of missions the military unit can provide on a daily basis.
Adjust firing techniques to mitigate smoke exposure to personnel, roadways, and smoke sensitive populations.
Determine appropriate fireline tactics, including indirect and direct attach strategies.
Report special incidents/accidents utilizing the SAFECOM system or other appropriate means. Arrange for accident investigation team if warranted.
Anticipate demobilization, identify excess resources, prepare demobilization schedule.
Maintain at least 10 percent water capacity in tank for emergency engine protection and drafting.
Communicate changing conditions to assigned resources.
Use Look Up, Down and Around in IRPG to help maintain situational awareness. Adjust actions accordingly. Develop and communicate contingency plans and trigger points.
Contact home agency with status of travel schedule.
Participate in the development of saw related objectives, priorities, work assignments, and performance expectations of saw team members.
Follow pay guidelines for compensation regarding sickness and medical treatment.
Communicate changing conditions to supervisor.
Ensure retardant use summary is accurately maintained.
Plan for demobilization. Brief assigned resources on demobilization procedures and responsibilities and ensure incident and agency demobilization procedures are followed.

Coordinate with the local Safety Officer to enforce compliance with all agency, local, and state health and safety requirements. Responsible for the maintenance and update of the base safety and security plan, Incident/Accident Action Plan, and Aviation Mishap Response Guide and Checklist.
Recognize and identify resource shortages.
Travel to and check in at assignment
Participate in briefings and After Action Reviews (AARs).

Adhere to guidelines in the NWCG Standards for Interagency Incident Business Management, PMS 902, for work/rest, length of assignment, determining when travel is compensable, ensuring adherence to ordered standby guidelines, and validating submitted time in accordance with Incident Operations Driving Standards.
Receive and process orders for all other Area Command functions.

Support aviation flight operations:
Process specific types of aircraft orders including infrared requests, radio frequencies, and portable Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) towers.
Follow national and local procedures for using contracted Call When Needed (CWN) aircraft to fill orders.
Provide daily data on number of gallons of retardant dropped and aircraft costs.
Monitor and/or track flight hours and report to appropriate personnel.
Inform other dispatch centers and the Geographic Area Coordination Center (GACC) of tactical aircraft availability.
Complete Temporary Flight Restrictions (TFR) form and create resource order.  Immediately notify FAA, Regional Airspace Coordinator, and military of TFR intrusions.
Coordinate with military on the use of airspace in Military Operations Areas (MOAs) and affected Military Training Routes (MTRs).
Coordinate incident infrared flight requests.
Coordinate and order radio frequencies as needed, including air-to-air and air-to-ground.
Operate transmitters and repeaters to provide communication to aircraft and incidents.
Ensure aircraft and pilots are carded and meet all agency, Department of the Interior, and Office of Aviation Service (OAS) requirements for the appropriate mission.
Determine and assign financial codes for aircraft fueling and flight time.
Demobilize resources from one or more of the functional areas.
Fall straight trees, in open areas, with no obstructions.
Conduct initial pilot in-briefing with contractor personnel. Review Base Operations Plan and local SOPs.
Fuel chainsaw before starting any cuts and have wedging tools readily available when felling hazard trees.
Utilize numbering system to track all vehicles and equipment assigned to the incident.
Review priorities for incidents and available resources with the supervisor.
Conduct initial pilot in-briefing with contractor personnel.
